title: Quiz 5: Head & Neck I (Structures)
description: Focused assessment on the skull osteology, triangles of the neck, root of the neck, face, scalp, and the thyroid gland.

questions.question: A blow to the side of the head at the 'Pterion' is dangerous because it can rupture which artery?
questions.explanation: The Pterion (temple) overlies the anterior branch of the Middle Meningeal Artery. Rupture causes an Extradural Hematoma.
questions.hint: It runs between the skull and the dura.

questions.question: Which of the following form the boundaries of the Posterior Triangle of the neck? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Boundaries: Anteriorly by Sternocleidomastoid, Posteriorly by Trapezius, Inferiorly by the Clavicle.
questions.hint: Think of the space behind the SCM muscle.

questions.question: Arrange the layers of the SCALP from superficial to deep:
questions.explanation: S-C-A-L-P: Skin, Connective tissue, Aponeurosis, Loose areolar tissue, Pericranium.
questions.hint: The mnemonic is the name of the region itself.

questions.question: Which structure passes through the Parotid Gland dividing it into superficial and deep parts?
questions.explanation: The Facial Nerve (CN VII) traverses the parotid gland, branching into its 5 terminal branches. It does NOT innervate the gland (which is supplied by CN IX).
questions.hint: Damage to this nerve during parotid surgery causes facial palsy.

questions.question: Match the muscle of mastication with its primary action:
questions.explanation: Lateral Pterygoid is the only muscle of mastication that OPENS the mouth. The others close it. Temporalis (posterior fibers) retracts.
questions.hint: L' for Lowering (Opening) - Lateral Pterygoid.

questions.question: The isthmus of the thyroid gland typically lies anterior to which tracheal rings?
questions.explanation: The thyroid isthmus crosses the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th tracheal rings.
questions.hint: Count from the cricoid cartilage down.

questions.question: The External Jugular Vein runs deep to the Sternocleidomastoid muscle.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The External Jugular Vein runs SUPERFICIAL to the Sternocleidomastoid. The Internal Jugular Vein runs DEEP to it (in the carotid sheath).
questions.hint: External is superficial; Internal is deep.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves are found in the Posterior Triangle of the neck? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Contents include the Spinal Accessory nerve (vulnerable to injury), Brachial Plexus trunks, and cutaneous branches of the Cervical Plexus. The Phrenic nerve is deep to the prevertebral fascia (on Scalenus Anterior).
questions.hint: The nerve supplying the Trapezius crosses here.

questions.question: The thoracic duct terminates by draining into the junction of the left ___BLANK___ vein and the left ___BLANK___ vein.
questions.explanation: The thoracic duct enters the venous angle (junction of Left IJV and Left Subclavian).
questions.hint: The two major veins forming the brachiocephalic.

questions.question: Which layer of the scalp contains the 'emissary veins', providing a route for infection to spread from the scalp to the intracranial sinuses?
questions.explanation: The Loose Areolar Tissue layer is the 'Danger Area' of the scalp because blood and pus can spread easily in it, and emissary veins can transmit infection inward to the dural sinuses.
questions.hint: The 'L' layer in SCALP.

questions.question: Review the diagram description. Which muscle separates the Subclavian Artery from the Subclavian Vein?

richContent.content: Root of Neck: The subclavian vein passes anterior to a specific scalene muscle, while the subclavian artery passes posterior to it.

questions.explanation: Scalenus Anterior is the key landmark. Vein is Anterior (VA), Artery is Posterior (AP). The Phrenic nerve runs on top of this muscle.
questions.hint: It is the most anterior of the scalene group.

questions.question: Match the branch of the External Carotid Artery with its distribution:
questions.explanation: Major branches: Superior Thyroid, Lingual, Facial, Occipital, Posterior Auricular, Ascending Pharyngeal. Terminals: Maxillary, Superficial Temporal.
questions.hint: The names generally indicate the destination.

questions.question: Which nerve runs vertically downwards on the anterior surface of the Scalenus Anterior muscle?
questions.explanation: The Phrenic nerve (C3, 4, 5) descends on the anterior surface of Scalenus Anterior to enter the thorax.
questions.hint: It keeps the diaphragm alive.

questions.question: Which of the following are subdivisions of the Anterior Triangle of the neck? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The anterior triangle is subdivided into the Digastric, Carotid, Muscular, and Submental triangles. The Supraclavicular (Omoclavicular) is part of the Posterior Triangle.
questions.hint: Triangles in front of the SCM.

questions.question: The parotid duct (Stensen's duct) pierces which muscle to enter the mouth opposite the second upper molar?
questions.explanation: The parotid duct crosses the Masseter but PIERCES the Buccinator to enter the oral cavity.
questions.hint: The 'trumpeter's muscle' in the cheek.

questions.question: Which foramen transmits the Middle Meningeal Artery?
questions.explanation: Foramen Spinosum transmits the Middle Meningeal artery. (Ovale = V3; Rotundum = V2).
questions.hint: It is a small 'spine-like' hole.

questions.question: The atlas (C1) vertebra has no body and no spinous process.
questions.explanation: TRUE. The atlas is a ring of bone with anterior and posterior arches. Its 'body' became the dens of the axis (C2).
questions.hint: It supports the globe (skull) on its shoulders.

questions.question: Which structure connects the facial vein to the cavernous sinus, providing a route for infection ('danger area of face')?
questions.explanation: The facial vein has no valves and connects via the Ophthalmic veins to the Cavernous Sinus. Squeezing spots in the danger area can cause Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis.
questions.hint: Veins draining the orbit.

questions.question: Arrange the branches of the Facial Nerve (from superior to inferior) as they exit the parotid gland:
questions.explanation: The hand on face mnemonic: Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Mandibular, Cervical. (To Zanzibar By Motor Car).
questions.hint: Think of spreading your fingers over your face.

questions.question: The superior thyroid artery is a branch of the ___BLANK___, while the inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Superior Thyroid <- External Carotid. Inferior Thyroid <- Thyrocervical Trunk <- Subclavian.
questions.hint: Superior comes from the carotid system; Inferior comes from the subclavian system.

questions.question: Which bones form the Pterion? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Pterion is the H-shaped junction of the Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, and Sphenoid bones.
questions.hint: The occipital bone is at the back; Pterion is at the side.

questions.question: Which lymphatic duct drains the lymph from the right side of the head, neck, thorax, and the right upper limb?
questions.explanation: The Right Lymphatic Duct drains the upper right quadrant. The Thoracic Duct drains the rest of the body.
questions.hint: It is not the thoracic duct.

questions.question: Which muscle divides the anterior triangle into the digastric, carotid, and muscular triangles?
questions.explanation: The superior belly of the Omohyoid and the Digastric muscles are the key dividers of the anterior triangle.
questions.hint: A muscle with two bellies connected by an intermediate tendon.

questions.question: Match the skull foramina with their contents:
questions.explanation: Cribriform = I. Optic = II. SOF = Eye movers + V1. Jugular = IX, X, XI.
questions.hint: Group them by cranial nerve number order.

questions.question: The facial nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the face.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The Facial Nerve (VII) provides MOTOR supply to facial muscles. The Trigeminal Nerve (V) provides SENSORY supply to the face.
questions.hint: Think about Trigeminal Neuralgia (sensory pain).
